text: [Music]
professor Chris Fisher is an
archaeologist at Colorado State
University
so lidar is a technology that allows you
to fully document everything from the
ground surface to the highest thing on
the ground when mounted on a plane lidar
sins a grid of laser beams down to the
surface below their reflections produce
a map of the ground it turns out that
even in the thickest jungle if you lie
on the ground and look up you will
always see little bits of blue sky here
and there and these billions and
billions of laser beams find every
little hole in the jungle canopy the
plane scanned 55 square miles of virgin
forests using sophisticated computer
software the vegetation was removed
revealing something surprising so in
this area of the Americas architecture
was made from earth but over time of
course earth and mud erodes so what you
end up with after many centuries after
abandonment our mounds the lidar shows
four cigar shaped mounds around a
central flat plaza so as an
archaeologist when we see these kinds of
mounds then we know automatically that
we're dealing with some kind of human
future
